_comment: Created by ianb on 27/04/2015 18:16:13 using v2.5
title: How have conception rates changed over time?
analysis_commentary:
The rate of conception in under-18s has been decreasing over time from 47.7 per 1,000 population in 1990, to 24.5 per 1,000 population in 2013 â€“ this is a decrease of 48.6%. The rate of decline seems to have been greater from 2007 onwards. In 1999, the Teenage Pregnancy Strategy was launched, which included a target to halve the under-18 conception rate between 1998 and 2010. Although progress in reducing the under-18 conception rate was made, we can see that the target of 23.3 per 1,000 population was missed by over ten conceptions per 1,000 population. Despite the end of this strategy in 2010, the conception rate continues to fall in 2013.

Despite this positive trend, when compared to other countries, UK still has one of the highest birth rates to women aged 15-17, while Denmark, Slovenia, the Netherlands and Sweden the lowest (see http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/vsob1/births-by-area-of-usual-residence-of-mother--england-and-wales/2012/sty-international-comparisons-of-teenage-pregnancy.html).
data_source: Office of National Statistics, Conception Statistics
